title: 106_hr825
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Macau Policy Act of 1999". The Congress recognizes the agreement between China and Portugal regarding the sovereignty of Macau, with China resuming sovereignty on December 20, 1999. Macau will enjoy a high degree of autonomy except in defense and foreign affairs. The Congress supports the "one country, two systems" policy for Macau, ensuring its autonomy in lifestyle, legal, social, and economic systems until 2049. Macau's legislature is elected, agreements from before 1999 remain valid, and new agreements can be made. Congress wishes for full implementation of the Joint Declaration. The Congress supports the "one country, two systems" policy for Macau until 2049. It emphasizes Macau's economic prosperity, democratization, and human rights as key principles in US foreign policy towards Macau. The successful transition of sovereignty over Macau must safeguard human rights. The successful transition of sovereignty over Macau must safeguard human rights, which also serve as a basis for Macau's economic prosperity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Macau" refers to the Macau Special Administrative Region of China. The term "Joint Declaration" refers to the agreement between China and Portugal on Macau. The term "laws of the United States" refers to laws enacted by Congress. The Congress believes the US should support Macau's prosperity, cultural heritage, and autonomy in various areas as outlined in the Joint Declaration with China and Portugal. The US should support Macau's prosperity, cultural heritage, and autonomy in various areas as outlined in the Joint Declaration with China and Portugal, consistent with national security interests. Title II of the document focuses on the status of Macau in United States law, specifically addressing the continued application of United States law in the region. Title II of the document addresses the continued application of United States law in Macau, stating that US laws will remain in effect after December 20, 1999, unless otherwise specified. International agreements and treaties between the US and Macau or Portugal will also continue unless lawfully terminated. The President has the authority to modify or terminate treaties with Macau if deemed necessary. Export control policies for Macau must be established within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The President has the authority to establish control policies and regulations in the national security interests of the United States. The President has the authority to issue a presidential order in the national security interests of the United States. The President may issue an Executive order suspending the application of a law to Macau if it is not sufficiently autonomous. The President must notify the relevant congressional committees of any such determination. In making this decision, the President should consider the terms of the Joint Declaration regarding Macau. The President can issue an Executive order suspending a law in Macau if it lacks autonomy, with notification to Congress. The order must be published in the Federal Register and can be terminated when Macau regains enough autonomy. The President is authorized to prescribe rules and regulations to carry out the Act. In doing so, consultation with Congress is required. Reporting requirements are outlined in Title III. The Secretary of State must provide reports on conditions in Macau to the Committee on International Relations and the Committee on Foreign Relations, covering significant developments in US relations with Macau and changes in sovereignty affecting US interests. The report to the Committees on International Relations and Foreign Relations will include information on US implementation of export controls in Macau, laws suspended or terminated in Macau, and international agreements requiring presidential determinations. The report will also cover the development of democratic institutions in Macau, compliance with obligations under the Joint Declaration by China and Portugal, and Macau's participation in multilateral forums. SEC. 302. Separate part of country reports. Reports to Congress on a country-by-country basis must include a separate subreport on Macau under the state that exercises sovereignty over Macau.
